awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: A Large Stellar Library for Astronomical Research
awd_abstract_narration:
Astronomers need to know the detailed colors of stars ("spectra") at visible and infrared wavelengths to conduct research about stars, galaxies, and the regions outside of galaxies in the Universe (for example, understanding different groups of stars in galaxies).  The libraries of stellar spectra that we have today do not offer enough high-quality information to use for the studies of today's astronomers.  For this project, the investigators will build a large library of high-quality spectra for about 6000 stars using observations made on existing telescopes and instruments.  This project will serve the national interest as it promotes the progress of research in astronomy by providing high-quality standards for astronomers to use to do their research.  The investigators will make and use a teaching unit with a web app for introductory college astronomy education that will help students understand how astronomers can learn about populations of stars using spectra.  They will also train graduate students and run outreach activities.

Stellar spectral libraries underpin spectroscopic analysis in stellar, galactic, and extragalactic astronomy; they are fundamental for modeling stellar populations in galaxies.  Existing empirical stellar libraries have poor sampling in several important parts of the stellar parameter space, do not provide adequate wavelength coverage and spectral resolution for the state-of-the-art galaxy surveys, and often have poor flux calibration.  Theoretical stellar libraries are not yet realistic enough to match the observed colors of stars and galaxies; this reveals an incomplete understanding of important stellar physics.  To address these problems, the investigators will build a large, well-calibrated, high quality empirical stellar library of ~6000 stars with much more extensive coverage of stellar parameter space than previous efforts.  The spectra will cover the wavelength range of 3600-10,300Å at a resolution of R~2000, with better than 3% relative flux calibration.  It will be achieved by conducting parallel optical observations piggybacking on the APOGEE-2 survey as part of Sloan Digital Sky Survey-IV.  The investigators will develop and then use an instructional unit with a web app for college introductory astronomy education that will help students understand how astronomers can learn about the stellar populations of a galaxy from its spectrum.  The investigators will also train graduate students and conduct outreach activities.

por.por_cntn:
In this project, we have constructed a large, high quality, library of empirical spectra of stars including nearly all types of stars, hot and cool ones, dwarfs, subgiants, giants, and supergiants, and with different chemical abundance patterns. The library is called the MaStar library. In total, the library contains 59,266 high quality spectra for 24,130 unique stars. Each star can have one or more spectra observed on different nights, for verification of flux calibration and to sample the variability.  The library will be extremely useful for a wide range of astronomical research, include the modeling of galaxy spectra to understand their star formation history, chemical enrichment history, and to remove stellar light in order to measure the emission lines from their interstellar medium. The library could also be used to model individual stars for galactic astronomy.

The observation took place during the past 6 years from 2014 to 2020 using the 2.5m Sloan Foundation Telescope at the Apache Point Observatory in New Mexico. We took great care in selecting the targets, reducing the data, calibrating them, and processing the data through a dedicated data processing pipeline to produce the final set of spectra. We carefully evaluated the quality of all the spectra to remove problematic ones, including visual inspection of a large fraction of them. The result is the MaStar library presented.The spectra covera wavelengths from 362.2nm to 1035.4nm with a median spectral resolution of R~1800. The relative flux calibration is accurate to 5% over 90% of the wavelength range.

Compared to the previous stellar library efforts, we have significantly expanded the coverage of stellar parameter space, in terms of effective temperature, surface gravity, overall abundance of heavy elements (characterized by iron-to-hydrogen ratio), and the relative abundance between alpha elements and iron. We also significantly increased the sampling density compared to previous efforts as we have a much larger sample.

A portion of the data were already released through Sloan Digtial Sky Survey's Data Release 16. All the data will be publicly released through the Sloan Digtial Sky Survey's Data Release 17, currently scheduled for December 2017.

The attached figure shows an Hertzsprung-Russell diagram for the stars in our library, color-coded with the log of their iron-to-hydrogen ratio relative to the Sun. The horizontal axis plots the colors of the stars measured using the Gaia Blue and Red bandpasses and corrected for the reddening effect by dust. The vertical axis plots the absolute magnitudes, or luminosities, of the stars measured in the Gaia G band, also corrected for dust. This shows the comprehensive stellar parameter coverage of the MaStar library.

Besides the broader impact on the astronomical community in general, we have also trained a few graduate students to do research in astronomy. They have learned extensive skills in conducting astronomical observations, processing and analyzing the data, and constraining stellar parameters from the spectra. Most importantly, they have learned and practiced their critical thinking skills problem solving skills, and acquired a range of computational skills that could be used in their future careers, in academic or industry. We have also developed a teaching module to enhance the teaching of introductory astronomy courses in colleges and universities. It teaches the students how astronomers uses spectra of galaxies to analyze the composition of stars in them and to find out about their star formation history. We also did a press release in January 2019 to advertise the release of the first version of the MaStar library, which is well received in the media.
